Line 11: Line 11:
:"The wives of men of rank when they die are not given at once to be embalmed, nor such women as are very beautiful or of greater regard than others, but on the third or fourth day after their death (and not before) they are delivered to the embalmers. They do so about this matter in order that the embalmers may not abuse their women, for they say that one of them was taken once doing so to the corpse of a woman lately dead, and his fellow-craftsman gave information."</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Brill | first1 = Abraham A. | year = 1941 | title = Necrophilia | url = | journal = Journal of Criminal Psychopathology | volume = 2 | issue = 4| pages = 433â443 }}</ref><ref name="klaf"/>
:"The wives of men of rank when they die are not given at once to be embalmed, nor such women as are very beautiful or of greater regard than others, but on the third or fourth day after their death (and not before) they are delivered to the embalmers. They do so about this matter in order that the embalmers may not abuse their women, for they say that one of them was taken once doing so to the corpse of a woman lately dead, and his fellow-craftsman gave information."</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Brill | first1 = Abraham A. | year = 1941 | title = Necrophilia | url = | journal = Journal of Criminal Psychopathology | volume = 2 | issue = 4| pages = 433â443 }}</ref><ref name="klaf"/>
â
In some societies the practice was enacted owing to a belief that the soul of an unmarried woman would not find peace; among the [[Jingpo|Kachin]] of [[Myanmar]], versions of a marriage ceremony were held to lay a dead virgin to rest, which would involve intercourse with the corpse. Similar practices existed in some pre-modern [[Central Europe]]an societies when a woman who was engaged to be married died before the wedding.
+
In some societies the practice was enacted owing to a belief that the soul of an unmarried woman would not find peace; among the [[Jingpo|Kachin]] of [[Myanmar]], versions of a marriage ceremony were held to lay a dead virgin to rest, which would involve intercourse with the corpse. Similar practices existed in some pre-modern [[Central Europe]]an societies when a woman who was engaged to be married died before the wedding.
  +   +
Necrophilia is often carried out by funeral directors. This is a followed by the catholic sect of the occupation, as many of the directors believe that releasing live semen into the body of one that has passed away can help guide the spirit of the dead to heaven. Those that practise this seem to follow a belief that the live semen will help swim the soul out of purgatory.
==Religious aspect==
==Religious aspect==
